story:
Hi my name is Lauren, I am 19 years old and live on the Isle of Skye.

In the last week I have been diagnosed with high grade non-hodgkin lymphoma which is a fast growing cancer of the lymphatic system.

I had been growing my hair out over lockdown with the intention of cutting my hair for charity however, My consultant has advised that I may lose my hair from the treatment so instead of letting cancer take my hair from me I am choosing to shave my head on my own terms. As I am due to start chemotherapy next week I will be getting my head shaved on Thursday 3rd December, the day before my first treatment session. I would like to make this a more positive experience by raising funds for macmillan cancer support who help people like me who are affected by cancer. This doesn’t leave long to raise funds so hoping to spread the word as quickly as possible to make this successful. 

All support is appreciated.

story:
In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation.

Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.

We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society.

A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

story:
Every day brings new challenges at Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH). Every day, 619 children and young people from across the UK arrive for life-changing treatments. 

Every day, young lives hang in the balance as patients, families and staff battle the most complex illnesses. Every day, the brightest minds come together to achieve pioneering medical breakthroughs that change the lives of thousands of children – and change the world.

Despite the greatest challenges a child can face, the hospital is a place where being sick does not always mean being sad. And it’s a place where you’ll find – today and every day – some of the bravest people you could ever meet.

This extraordinary hospital has always depended on charitable support, and every day is a chance for you to make a difference

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Hope all is well,

So this year has been a very strange year and at times a
very challenging one no doubt for everyone, Yesterday I was speaking with a
Charity Co-ordinator Amanda at Marie Curie Hospice in Glasgow, The Hospice for
those who don’t know is in the grounds of Stobhill Hospital in G21, Amanda mentioned that the charity has struggled a bit this year with donations due to the pandemic and that the hospice was very different in the lead up to Christmas with no decorations allowed inside the hospice, I got in touch with Amanda last year after spending my Christmas Day with my Gran at the Hospice this was one of my Grans last days but I feel blessed I got to spend one last Christmas with her and it wouldn’t have been as special a day if it wasn’t for the effort of the Staff at Marie Curie who made every effort to give those patients and families in the hospice as good a Christmas day as possible given the circumstances, In The Hospice they have a very large out door Balcony which Most of the patients rooms view
onto and we are looking to raise fund for the charity to allow them to decorate this area with outdoor Christmas Lights and Decorations, with Christmas being just around the corner we have a very tight deadline for this and to start the fund raising off Sky have donated £100, I'm now reaching out to this great region for help if you could donate anything to the just giving page or if you have any new outdoor decorations you could donate please get in touch we hope to
have everything in place next week by the 2nd of December as always
your help and generosity would be greatly appreciated.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I’ve made some Christmas tree decorations and small art frames from clay pipe stems I’ve found mudlarking on the Thames. Rather than sell them all in my Megasteg Etsy shop I’ve decided to try and use them to fundraise for Marie Curie by offering them as raffle prizes. Here’s how it will work:

Every donation made will count as a single raffle entry. There is no minimum donation and you may enter as many times as you like. Please include your Instagram account name in your donation message so I can DM you if you win. Feel free to tag yourself in my Instagram post about the raffle to let me know you’ve donated too.

I will draw the raffle on 10th December and inform the winner(s). I will publish the draw on my megasteg Instagram account. Last time for entries is 7pm GMT on 10th December.

The prize will be a set of 3 clay pipe stem tree decorations made from clay pipe stems, beads and gold/silver foil leaf. There will be one winner. 

If total donations exceed £50 there will be 2 prizes; a pipe stem art frame and a set of 3 clay pipe stem tree decorations. There will be two winners, the first receiving the art frame and the second receiving the tree decorations.

If total donations exceed £100 there will be 3 prizes; a pipe stem art frame, a set of 3 clay pipe stem tree decorations and a set containing one of each. There will be three winners, the first receiving both an art frame and a set of decorations, the second receiving an art frame and the third receiving a set of tree decorations.

Items will be posted to the winners at my own expense. I will ship worldwide but can’t guarantee Christmas delivery (but I will ship as soon as I have the winners’ addresses following the draw). 

Please consider donating at least £1 just to make it worthwhile for the charity as well as the fact that Justgiving take a small percentage to cover administrative costs.

Thank you for participating!

Kind regards

Sam

story:
RNLI Blackpool is launching an appeal to raise £52,000 to fund a new D-class Lifeboat for Blackpool Lifeboat Station. 

  
D-class lifeboats are fundamental to the search and rescue service provided at Blackpool.  The D-class lifeboat first came to Blackpool in 1964 and have rescued hundreds of people and saved many lives over the years.  Colin Lowe, volunteer lifeboat helm said Our D class lifeboats enable us to carry out lifesaving rescues in the tricky surf conditions at Blackpool.  Without the unique capabilities of this class of lifeboat we simply couldnt help the number of people that we do.  We are hoping to raise £52,000 for a new D class lifeboat to continue saving lives at sea in Blackpool.  

Every little helps, thank you so much for your support.

charity.description:
We’re the world’s leading independent conservation organisation. And we’re building a future where people and nature thrive together. 

That’s why we’re passionate about sharing the planet’s resources more sustainably, tackling climate change and protecting endangered wildlife.
charity.name: WWF-UK
story:
2020 has been a difficult year for all of us in one way or another. The global human cost of the pandemic is incomprehensible and a stark reminder that to some extent we are all at the mercy of nature.

COVID-19 and Climate Change are both global challenges which pose a threat to human existence and require a united effort to find solutions (UNICEF, 2020). More generally there is evidence that climate change and human impact on the environment are increasing the emergence of infectious diseases (WHO, 2020). In order to reduce the risk of outbreak of new diseases in the future, across the globe we must improve our health systems, improve surveillance of infectious diseases and protect and improve biodiversity and the natural environment (WHO, 2020).

COVID-19 has had an impact on the environment and the climate. During the early stages of the pandemic and the first national lockdowns, noticeable improvements in air quality were seen in cities across the world. In early April daily global carbon emissions were down 17% on the 2019 value for the same period (Le Quéré et al., 2020). A study in Italy (the first country to impose a national lockdown) found evidence of increases in species richness, increased breeding success of some bird species and reduced road killing of some amphibians and reptiles (Manenti et al., 2020). However, we all know that it is not all good news. The pandemic has caused a surge in
demand for single use plastics and production of huge amounts of medical waste. During the peak of the pandemic in Wuhan China, 247 tonnes of medical waste was produced each day, 6 times more than before the pandemic (Narendra et al., 2020). Across the world, much of the medical waste is incinerated, polluting the atmosphere (Gardiner, 2020). As governments draw up plans to tackle the health
crisis, environmental laws and enforcement of environmental regulations are being put on the back burner (Gardiner, 2020). As a result of illegal logging in the Amazon, 64% more land was cleared in April 2020 than in April 2019 (Reuters, 2020). Across the world, governments are reinforcing the oil and gas industries to shore up economies, and as countries began to emerge from the
first wave of the pandemic industrial activities were ramped up to make up for lost time (Gardiner, 2020). These impacts are ongoing and there is a desperate need for the world to recognise that as we tackle the health crisis, we must emerge greener and change our relationship with the natural world.

According to an online survey in Scotland, 76% of people agreed that access to green spaces and wildlife were important to their
wellbeing during the first lockdown (WWF, 2020a). During this time many of us enjoyed spending time outdoors and marvelling at the wildlife on our doorsteps. It was a great relief from the uncertainty and stress that the coronavirus was imposing on our lives and provided reassurance that we need not despair. Indeed we are still reaping these benefits from nature. For me a morning walk along
the river to watch the salmon leaping and the otters play and to admire the beautiful fiery colours of the trees and gentle fall of the amber leaves makes my heart smile and gives me a sense of peace and place in this strange new world. Without this I would be lost. We would all be lost.

To this end we have decided to support WWF with whom
we share the vision of a world where people and wildlife can thrive together. To achieve this mission the WWF are working ‘to find ways to help transform the future for the world’s wildlife, rivers, forests and seas; pushing for a reduction in carbon emissions that will avoid catastrophic climate change; and pressing for measures to help people live sustainably, within the means of our one planet.’ (WWF, 2020b).

This is entirely optional and we are grateful that you have taken the time to read this.

Shannon and Molly
